Mission Statement and Core Values
Mission Statement
“At Accent Roofing Service it is our mission to provide each client with the best contractor experience they
have ever had.”
Our relentless commitment is to redefine excellence in the roofing industry, driven by three crucial
objectives:
1. Setting a new standard for contractor service and client satisfaction.
2. Sustaining a culture which cultivates personal and professional growth and enables each member
of the team to thrive in their career and in life.
3. Pursuing growth based on sincerity, transparency, and unwavering commitment to our clients and
our craft.
Core Values
1. Honesty
2. Forthrightness
3. Consistency
4. Diligence
5. Persistence
6. People over profits

Type Three Roofing Company
There are two types of roofing companies:
Type One: companies that are big with a client experience that is lacking and high turnover; Type Two:
small to medium sized outfits whose ownership has hands in everything and refuses to delegate for fear
that anything delegated will be done in a way that is less than or watered down from how they would do
it.
Which type is Accent Roofing Service????
If you want to build a great roofing company, how can you follow either blueprint and realize your goals?
Is there a rarely realized Type Three? Can a company be highly profitable, and have significant growth
potential while still delivering the same high-quality experience that they delivered in the early years?
I have wrestled with this for years. At times I was close to believing you had to pick one or the other, but
I still wasn’t convinced; one of few scenarios where I believe being hardheaded has served me well.
Finally, after many years without certainty on this matter I can now say I have certainty. Type Three can
exist, and it does exist in Accent Roofing Service. We have found a way through years of brainstorming,
trial and error, searching for great people, setbacks, and leaps forward to provide the best contractor
experience each of our clients has ever had, while also maintaining and increasing profit, and most
importantly protecting and helping to facilitate a great quality of life for each of the people that make up
this company.
This is my vision and hope for Accent Roofing Service, and each person on the Accent Roofing Service
team.
Phillip Scribbins
President

The T-Bird Way
1. Make it to all appointments 15 minutes early. If running more than 15 minutes late, notify Confirmation
45 minutes before your appointment time so they can advise the client of your arrival time. DO NOT call
the client directly (they may attempt canceling and rescheduling the appointment.)
TARDINESS IS THE THEFT OF A CLIENT’S TIME! BE ON TIME!
2. Offer to take your shoes off when entering the home or put on boot covers.
The client will usually say no, but it shows you are civilized and considerate. In some cases, you
probably won’t get the deal if you do not offer to take off your shoes.
3. Hand the client a business card at the door.
4. Follow the 5-step Flow Chart to Success.
5. Upload photos of any unusual or unique aspects of the project to Jobber.
6. Whether one-call-closed or not, leave a complete presentation folder with the client.
7. Customize the estimate details and include notes in the note section on Jobber.
8. Get the color selection or leave a sample book on every appointment.
9. Whether one-call-closed or not, send the estimate that they approved or send the estimate that you
walked them down to, with the cover email letter customized prior to leaving the driveway.
*Only exception would be pricing-related delays that prevent quote completion and that time.
10. Get a client photo with a warranty certificate if one-call-closed.
11. Write lead results in the request notes (request is what we call an appointment in Jobber.)
Copy and paste them to the sales string on Crew, upload photos as needed to the Jobber request, save,
then mark the appointment as complete.
12. If sold, get a deposit, convert the quote to a job within 24 hours, and have the paperwork posted within
48 hours.
13. If not sold, follow up and negotiate, then leave notes on the original Jobber request.
14. Make the post-job follow-up call; ask for a review and referrals.
15. New requirement! If a client is a no-show, wait 30 minutes, have the office call the client, then put a
business card in the door and take a photo. Notify the CONTACT BOX to attempt rescheduling.
The Daily Appointment Checklist on Page 29 is a more simplified document that should be followed each
day to ensure maximum potential, great client service, and smooth operations for the rest of the team.

What Is a GAF Master Elite Roofing Contractor
In the absence of a state mandated roofing trade license the next best thing a roofing contractor can do in
Georgia to show expertise, and credibility is to get certified through one of the top 3 roofing material
manufacturers. The top 3 are GAF, CertainTeed, and Owens Corning. Each manufacturer has different
qualifications for a roofer to acquire certification. GAF’s standards are the most rigorous, and in effect the
most prestigious.
GAF has different levels of Certification. The first level is GAF certified, which requires 3 or more years in
business, valid workers comp and liability insurance, good standing with the BBB, and yearly training. GAF
certified contractors can only install the GAF System plus roof system.
GAF certified plus contractors must meet all the same requirements as certified contractors and be certified
for 2 years. They can sell the GAF System plus roof system, and the GAF Silver pledge roof system.
The highest level of GAF certification is GAF Master elite. There are 3 levels for this certification, 1 star, 2 stars,
and 3 stars. 1 start Master elite roofers must maintain all the same requirements as certified, and certified
plus, and have 5 years in business minimum. To maintain their certification or advance to the next stage they
must also meet rigorous warranty requirements, more in depth training, a 4.5 or better rating on Google, and
sell a certain number of products each year. There must also be an opening, as GAF will not allow any more
than 2% of all roofing contractors to be part of the Master elite program. GAF master elite roofer can sell all
GAF advanced warranties including the Golden pledge roof system which can only be sold and installed by
master elite roofers.
Accent Roofing Service is currently a GAF 3-star roofing contractor as of January 1st, 2025. We should be
getting 3-star status by mid-year.
The “so what” for why Master elite certification is valuable to our clients is as follows: By hiring a master elite
roofing contractor you can get the most robust warranties in the industry that only they can install, which come
with the best materials, and random GAF quality inspections. You can also be certain that the contractor has at
minimum met the vetting requirements of the largest roofing material manufacturer in the country.
GAF master elite roofing contractors make up the top 2% of all roofing contractors in the country.

Why the Basics Matter
Later in this handbook and in your training, you will learn what we refer to at L5S as the “Basics”. They aren’t
routine busywork — they’re the foundation of long-term success. These daily habits may seem small or
disconnected, but when practiced consistently, they build momentum, sharpen your skills, and elevate the
entire team.
Here’s how each habit works in your favor:
• Post-Job Calls & Reviews
Reflecting on the client’s experience builds sincerity and trust — key traits of a great salesperson.
• Follow-Ups (see the Lead follow up protocol in the SOP’s chapter)
Shows tenacity and reinforces long-term relationships with clients and makes you a more successful
salesperson.
• Notes, Quotes, & Photos (A list of photos that need to be taken are listed in the SOP’s chapter)
Improves memory, builds confidence, and ensures you’re always prepared. This too makes you a more
complete salesperson.
• Voting in the Group Chat
It may seem minor, but voting builds a team-first mindset. It ties you to our shared reputation and
reminds you that your participation matters. This sense of ownership boosts sincerity, pride, and
personal accountability, which makes you a more successful salesperson.
• Training & Repetition (this entire handbook is a resource that should be learned backwards and
forwards as the foundation of your success as a Thunderbird)
Deepens knowledge and turns information into instinct. Over time, it builds mastery in your role as a
roofing consultant and salesperson.
Commit to these basics every day — not just for a week or a month, but until the results speak for themselves.
Some benefits are immediate; others take time. But one thing is certain: consistency creates unstoppable
momentum. And with momentum, there’s no limit to how far you can go.

Appointment Types and Acronyms
1. RE: This stands for repair estimate:
These are roofs under 13 years of age, generally with leaks, missing shingles, or other cosmetic or
functional issues. These clients generally are of the opinion that they do not need a replacement, only
the current problem resolved. Homeowners are not the experts. When you go to a RE, you should still
check the conditions of the entire roof from aging to storm damage and make your recommendations
accordingly.
2. REO: This stands for repair estimate on an old roof 14 year or older:
Generally, with leaks, missing shingles, or other cosmetic or functional issues. These clients generally
are of the opinion that they do not need a replacement, only the current problem resolved. You should
check these roofs thoroughly for wear and tear and determine if ARS can properly repair the roof
without creating additional damage. In some cases, a repair will be out of the question, in other cases a
repair will be an option, but a replacement may be the better option depending on how much life is left
on the roof.
3. IC: This stands for insurance contingency:
These are clients that think they have storm damage or another covered loss of some kind. On these
appointments you should ask the client what problems they are having, inspect any active leaks, get the
name of their insurance company, inspect for hail wind, and other damage, and if valid claim move
forward with the claim filing process.
4. OOP: This stands for Out-of-Pocket full replacement:
This type of appointment is a client that is actively shopping for a new roof. If they have covered storm
damage and we can get insurance to pay we still need to discuss that, but in most cases, this will be a
retail replacement.
5. Inspection:
This is a $400 inspection appointment. You will need to do a complete roof inspection, documenting all
issues, conditions etc. of the roof then convert it to a report through Google Docs or CompanyCam.
***Sometimes these appointments will be combined for example IC/OOP, or RE/OOP. In those cases, there is a
clear circumstance where the client is unsure of what they need.
***Appointment types are based on info gathered by confirmation at the time the appointment is scheduled. It is
vital to remember that most clients are not aware of all options, and do not know what they need to do. It is our
job to keep an open mind despite the way the appointment is labeled, gather all necessary information, and

No Stone Left Unturned
In our industry, there are two primary ways to generate business: self-generated opportunities through door
knocking and networking, and marketing that drives homeowners to invite us into their homes.
Both approaches have value. The strongest strategy combines them, but let’s be honest—successful
marketing in roofing is extremely difficult, especially for smaller companies. And on the other side, most
people simply will not knock doors.
Having weighed both approaches and tested them as a company, we designed Accent Roofing Service to
thrive on strong marketing and brand recognition. Each year we invest hundreds of thousands of dollars into
campaigns that build trust and keep homeowners reaching out to us. This model allows us to scale
consistently while offering our Thunderbirds daily appointments and opportunities without requiring them to
self-generate.
Of course, this comes with both risks and rewards. The greatest risk of a marketing-driven sales model is what
we call “lead baby syndrome.” This occurs when sales representatives begin to take a steady stream of leads
for granted—complaining when a lead isn’t perfect, writing opportunities off too quickly, or failing to follow up
with the energy and professionalism that wins business.
To combat this, we embrace what we call the No Stone Left Unturned Mindset.
This mindset means treating every lead as if it cost $300—because it does. It means approaching every
opportunity with the question: “How can I turn this into a win?” And it means being resourceful enough to turn
what might seem like “chicken scratch” into chicken salad.
Winning looks different in different situations. Here are three ways you can win with any lead:
1. The obvious win: Sell the client the roofing services they truly need.
2. The referral win: Provide an honest, detailed assessment. If no work is needed, point the homeowner in
the right direction, ask for a review, share cards, and introduce them to our referral program.
3. The long-term win: Make a strong impression, sow good seed, and follow the follow-up protocol. Even
if they don’t buy today, you either win them later—or you learn what could have gone better, making you
stronger for the future.
No stone left unturned means squeezing every drop of value out of every opportunity.
When you adopt this mindset, you’ll find yourself developing a grateful heart—which leads to a continual feast.
That feast is not just symbolic; it shows up in your success, income, quality of life, and sense of purpose.
Now, for those rare few with the fire to not just succeed but to achieve elite status in sales, the No Stone Left
Unturned Mindset can be applied beyond your leads to every aspect of your career. This looks like:
• Leaving door hangers at neighboring homes after every appointment
• Visiting job sites to connect with clients and attract neighbors
• Handing out cards at social events, little league games, or community gatherings
• Promoting yourself consistently on social media

• Watching for homeowner posts on platforms like Nextdoor or Reddit and engaging them
• Even knocking on a door or two if opportunity strikes
Greatness here comes from working every lead with discipline and gratitude. But excellence—record-breaking,
goal-crushing excellence—comes from combining that discipline with proactive, self-generating habits.
Adopt the No Stone Left Unturned mindset, and there will be no limits to what you achieve.

The 5-Step Flow Chart to Sales Success!
Step One—Getting Off to a Solid Start
A. Initial Client Interaction
1. Look at the Hail Trace Report to see if there are valid hail or wind dates. Know the client’s name.
2. Knock, greet the client by name, and hand out your card as you introduce yourself.
3. Initial small talk should be kept minimal; you will talk more after making the initial impression as
professional, courteous, and knowledgeable.
4. The full extent of small talk for Step One should be:
o pleasantries,
o questions, and
o using their name two or three times (mostly so YOU remember it).
B. Client Inquiry
1. Ask them what the problem is, how old the roof is, how long it’s been going on, have they ever had
roofing work done before, how did it go, what made them decide to do it today,
2. Take note of their answer; if they are ready to go, you can speed the process up by assuming they are
ready to sign.
Step Two—Inspection, Game Plan, and Estimates
A. Interior Inspection
1. Tell them you would like to see the areas where the interior is being damaged.
2. Put boot covers on or take your shoes off (nonnegotiable).
3. Have them show you any staining or leaking inside the home.
4. If there is no interior damage, tell them that you still need to check the attic.
5. Get photos of any interior damage or relevant interior images.
Point out the reasons why we need to inspect the attic:
o Light and leaks (Light = leaks, plus possible termites/carpenter ants)
o Ventilation (Construction code vs. engineering ideal)
o Looking for damaged or improperly installed decking (rot and staining is huge)
o Mold or signs of moisture
o issing insulation/insulation blocking soffit vents
o Freon line placement

E. Get Your Game Face on and Be Prepared to Consult
1. Fill in your CPO sheet, know the photos you will use during the demo, have all estimates created, and
your presentation folder, iPad, demo bag, and samples ready to go.
Step Three—Consultation
A. Initial Approach
1. Regardless of whether this is going to be insurance, repair, or replacement, the goal is to get to a sitting
position with the client so that you can comfortably go through all your findings.
o Ideally, you should knock on the door again and ask if you could come in to go over your
findings. Usually, this will lead to sitting at the kitchen table or counter, but sometimes they take
you to a couch.
o Speak up and say it would be best if we had a table. People will be fine with this request.
o If you are stopped at the door and they are pushing for the estimate or being rude, you will have
to call an audible.
o If stopped at the door, explain that you have photos and videos to go over with them. If they still
resist, ask if they can come outside and tell them you will use the back of your car/truck.
o If they agree to use your car/truck hood, you can proceed as usual. If they still insist on getting
down to brass tacks, hand them the presentation folder, tell them that it has “everything they

Insurance 101
Insurance inspection terminology and definitions
1. HailTrace Report
A report required for every lead. It details the history of high-wind events (with wind speeds) and
hailstorms (with hail size) at or near the property.
2. Date of Loss
The date on which storm-related damage occurred to the property.
3. Covered Loss
Types of damage that are eligible for repair or replacement under a homeowner's insurance policy.
4. Carrier
Another term for the insurance company.
5. Bought or Approved
Terms used to describe a claim that has been approved by the insurance company for roof
replacement.
Examples: “The adjuster bought the roof” or “The adjuster approved the roof.”
6. Wind Damage
Damage caused by high winds, typically seen as missing or creased shingles.
7. Creased Shingles
A bend in an asphalt shingle caused by wind lifting and flipping the shingle backward. This leaves a
crease, similar to folding and unfolding a piece of paper. Most common in 3-tab shingles; creases in
architectural shingles may indicate vandalism.
8. Hail Damage
Damage resulting from hailstones striking the roof or surrounding structures. Common signs include
circular impact marks on shingles or dents in soft metals.
9. Hail Hit(s)
Visible impact marks on shingles or metal surfaces caused by hail.
o On shingles: Look for a darkened area or a crescent/moon-shaped mark.
o On metal: Look for circular dents.
o Note: Hail smaller than 0.75" typically does not cause shingle damage, but exceptions exist.
When reviewing a HailTrace report, look for hail events of 0.75" or larger.
10. Soft Metal
Metal components around the home, including gutters, downspouts, roof vents, siding vents, and even
mailboxes.
11. Collateral Damage
Damage to property features other than the roof—such as soft metals, doors, windows, screens,
awnings, patio umbrellas, and similar items.
12. Elevations
The four exterior walls of a property: front, right, rear, and left.
13. Spatter
Light-colored marks on surfaces with algae buildup (like roofs). These marks occur when hailstones
knock the algae off. While not considered hail damage, spatter indicates that hail was present and that
damage may be likely.
14. Blistering
A common reason insurers deny hail claims. Blisters are irregular, circular marks on shingles caused by
33

bubbles in the asphalt adhesive. They usually contain little to no granules and are not considered a
covered loss. Hail hits, by contrast, may have granules embedded into the matting.
15. Sliding Shingles
Shingles that have shifted due to wind exposure and/or improper installation. Wind may lift shingles off
their nails without fully detaching them, causing them to hang or slide down. Adjuster opinions vary on
whether this counts as damage.
16. Delaminated Shingles
A condition affecting architectural shingles when the two laminated layers begin to separate. This can
result from improper installation (missing the nail zone) or manufacturing defects. The unanchored
layer may slip, creating a "gapped tooth" appearance.
17. Test Square
A 10 ft x 10 ft chalked area on each directional slope of the roof. Adjusters count and mark hail hits
within this square. Generally, six or more hits per square are needed to qualify for a full replacement,
though this varies by carrier.
18. Repairability
A measure of whether a roof can be repaired rather than replaced. Assessed through a brittleness test,
visual inspection, or prior repair failures. A failed repairability test supports the case for full
replacement.
19. Brittleness Test
A method to determine if shingles are too brittle to be repaired.
o A shingle is loosened with a flat bar or putty knife, lifted to about a 45-degree angle, then laid
back down.
o If it bends without creasing, the shingle passes.
o If it creases or breaks, the shingle fails—supporting full roof replacement.
20. By Choice
A a type of insurance appointment where the claim is already approved (more detail on how to handle
later in this chapter.

Insurance Workflow
Step 1- Determine if there is a valid claim
a. Check the hailtrace report for valid dates of loss. If there are none within one year but there is visible
damage call to get advice.
b. Find out who the carrier is, and how long they have been insured by them. All insurance companies are
different. The big 2 (STATE FARM & ALLSTATE) have the most stringent qualifications for full roof
replacement. The easiest to get approved are (AMICA, ALPHA, TRAVELERS, NATIONWIDE, CHUBB,
QBE, HOMESITE, ENCOMPASS, LEMONADE, and
most small lesser-known companies), middle of the road companies are (USAA, FARMERS, and a few
others). Each company has a claim filing period from the date of loss, use 1 year as your baseline, if the
storm is more than a year out call and get advice from someone as to whether you should move
forward.
c. Ask the client if they have previously filed a claim on the roof, if so, what was the outcome of the claim.
If anything was approved, we need to know what it was and if the work was done. If work is approved
and not made the payments will come off any subsequent claim filed for the roof. Once this
information has been ascertained, move on to the next step.
d. Determine the age of the roof, 12 years or less will be challenging to get approved on wind alone with
the middle of the road and 2 big companies. 13 years plus are more likely to get approved on wind
claims due to lack of repairability. For hail claims if you have a valid date the age of the roof is less
important. Roofs as young as 3-5yrs old will get approved with hail damage.
e. Check for covered losses. Wind, hail, tree, vandalism…. These are all covered types of
damages/losses.
• Wind damage look for creased, sliding, and/or missing shingles. It’s best if there is damage on the
two main slopes (front/back, or right/left) depending on the structure of the roof, but the two slopes
that make up the most area. If there is only damage on one slope, or on lesser slopes but the roof is
still in bad shape you should still consider filing and should contact someone with more experience
for input.
• Hail damage look for collateral damage (damage to siding, gutters, downspouts, window screens,
awnings, garage doors, mailboxes, fence posts and deck posts, as well as AC condenser fins. The
collateral inspection should be done by walking the perimeter of the home, and checking each of
those areas as you go, documenting along the way by photo. Then check the roof via drone for soft
metal dents, and impact marks to the shingles. If you find that there are signs of hail damage
document with photos.
• Tree damage look for fallen limbs, sticks, or other debris that have caused damage to the roof,
document with photos. After gathering all necessary information (age, insurance company, claims
history, damage assessment) determine if there is a 50% or greater chance of the claim being
approved. If you don’t know that information call to consult with someone on the team with more
experience.
Step 2 - Filing and moving forward
a. Assuming there is a 50% or greater chance of the claim being approved you will follow the steps
outlined PS5 for filing a claim.

Terminology and Definitions (Insurance & Estimating Terms)
1. Scope
A common term used to refer to the insurance adjuster’s estimate.
2. Xactimate
A computer software program widely used to generate insurance estimates for property damage.
3. Symbility
Another software platform used to create insurance estimates, similar to Xactimate.
4. RCV (Replacement Cost Value)
The total amount of the estimate before depreciation or deductibles are subtracted. This is the highest
dollar amount listed on the estimate and represents the full cost to repair or replace damaged property.
5. ACV (Actual Cash Value)
The value of the estimate after depreciation has been deducted. It typically does not include removal of
the deductible at this stage.
6. Deductible
The portion of the claim the insurance company does not pay. It is subtracted from the ACV amount
before the first payment is issued to the homeowner.
7. Depreciation
The amount the insurance company subtracts from the claim to account for wear, age, and condition of
the damaged items.
8. Recoverable Depreciation
The portion of depreciation that can be paid back to the homeowner after the work is completed and a
Certificate of Completion (COC) with photo documentation is submitted for the full claim amount.
9. Non-Recoverable Depreciation
The portion of depreciation the insurance company will not reimburse, even after the work is
completed.
10. Law & Ordinance / Building Code Items
Upgrades or materials required by current building codes that were not present on the existing
structure. These items are only covered if the policy includes code coverage and are generally listed on
the estimate if they are approved.
11. PWI (Paid When Incurred)
A term used by State Farm and other carriers referring to code items or recoverable depreciation.

12. Summary of Loss
A key page in the claim documentation where all sections of the estimate are totaled, payments are
outlined, and policy benefits are summarized.
13. Replacement Cost Policy
An insurance policy that pays for approved repair or replacement work minus the deductible.
14. ACV Policy
An insurance policy that pays for approved work minus the deductible and minus depreciation.

1. Find the surface area, pitch, and number of facets of the roof on your aerial report.

100 to calculate your “off figure.”
4. Using the Consumption Chart, find the waste percentage of the roof using the number of facets.
5. Add 1. to the waste number, then multiply by your off figure to find your “on figure.” For example, if the
waste factor is 15% you would multiply the off figure by 1.15 to = on figure.
6. Multiply the on figure by the cost per square value for that type of roof.
7. Add in your side work, if any, then divide by the GPM factor from the GPM calculator to find your bid
amount.

Warranty Types
1. Material warranty
• Material warranties cover different types of materials on the roof in the event of a manufacturer
defect.
• Material warranties range from limited to full lifetime coverage. Limited generally covers the
shingles only at 100% for 1/5 of the timeline listed on the product. For example, a 25-year 3-tab
shingle with a limited warranty would cover shingles at 100% for up to 5 years, for an
architectural shingle that is considered a 50 year or lifetime product with a limited lifetime
warranty would have 100% coverage on shingles only for 10 years. A lifetime architectural
shingle sold with a full lifetime warranty would generally cover all roof system materials
including the shingles for 50 years at 100% coverage.
2. Labor warranty
• A labor warranty covers the cost of labor to replace materials if the material warranty coverage,
algae warranty coverage, or wind warranty coverage is triggered.
3. Workmanship warranty
• Workmanship warranties come in two forms.
a. Contractor backed
b. Manufacturer backed
• These warranties are intended to cover issues resulting from workmanship defects such as
leaking, or aesthetic issues.
• The average full roof workmanship warranty in Ga is 2 years.
• It is important for clients to read or ask about the exclusions to this warranty. Many private
equities owned roofing companies have severe limitations that release them from liability in the
event of leaking or other issues.
4. Algae warranty
• The algae warranty covers streaking or algae growth for varying periods of time.
• The most robust algae warranty is the GAF 25-year stainguard warranty.
• Many roof shingles do not include this warranty.
5. Wind warranty
• Wind warranties cover roofs against wind damage and are defined by a maximum wind speed.
• Generally architectural shingles are covered for up to 110mph, 3-tab shingles range from 60mph
to 80mph.

• Some architectural shingle wind warranties go above 110mph, for example the Owens Corning
duration shingle has a wind warranty up to 130mph, and GAF Timberline HDZ shingle has the
most robust warranty with no maximum wind speed limitation. Both the Owens Corning and
GAF warranties previously mentioned require specific installation instructions to be followed
regarding number of nails per shingle.

Lead Follow-Up SOP
Purpose:
Accent Roofing Service (ARS) invests heavily in acquiring leads as a show of trust in your professionalism and
dedication. These leads are loaned to each sales representative to generate revenue for both themselves and
ARS.
To protect this investment, ARS also maintains an Inside Sales Department to maximize each opportunity. If
follow-up protocol is not followed, leads will roll to Inside Sales to ensure every attempt is made to close the
deal and deliver a consistent, high-quality client experience.
Thunderbirds may run 2–4 leads per day for weeks or months, making it essential to balance new
opportunities with strong follow-up. In some cases, it may be in the best interest of both the client and the
sales rep to proactively pass the lead to Inside Sales before the official roll date.
Examples of when to hand off early:
• The client requires ongoing attention that prevents you from focusing on current leads.
• You’re bogged down with insurance overturn delays.
• You did not build strong rapport in the initial meeting.
Compensation for early hand-off:
• $150 flat commission when the job sells.
• Insurance overturns: commission and sales numbers are split 50/50 with Inside Sales after the sale.
Remember: $150 or half the deal is better than zero.
How to hand off:
Email Beth at beth@leaksmith.com with the details. She will take over, and update you if she closes the sale or
if an insurance claim is approved, so you can work together to ensure you are paid.
ARS Believes…
• A professional follow-up process is the easiest and most effective way to maintain an elite YPL.
• Leaving no stone unturned—and getting a definitive “YES” or “NO”—is critical to protecting our
marketing investment.
• Nurturing your pipeline creates repeat and referral business; every sold job should lead to one or two
more.
Day-by-Day Follow-Up Protocol
Note: All follow-up notes must be entered in the original appointment notes in Jobber. Once the job is sold,
subsequent notes will be attached to the sold job. Create a system to track your follow-ups. If unsure, follow
these steps.

Thank you for inviting Accent Roofing Service to bid on your roof project. It would be a privilege to work
on your home, and you can depend on me to do a great job for you.”

HVAC Line SOP
During certain roof replacement and repair projects, the HVAC line running from the attic unit may become an
obstacle, creating the potential for significant unforeseen expenses. The following protocols are in place to
minimize risk, costs, and potential damage to the client experience.
Preventative Measures
1. During all sales appointments, the Sales Representative will check the accessible attic.
a. While there, take photos of the freon line coming out of the attic-based HVAC unit.
i. If the line runs upward against the bottom of the roof decking, the Sales Representative
will note this detail in the PWS production notes. The Client Services Specialist will
address this issue with the client during the onboarding call, informing them that attic
access is needed before 9 am to work around the problem.
b. If the attic is inaccessible to the Sales Representative or the client was unavailable during the
initial sales visit, a note that effect is to be included in the PWS production notes. If the client
was unavailable during the initial sales visit, the Client Services Specialist will explain, during the
onboarding call, that the Project Manager needs access to the attic before 9 am on the day of
the roof replacement.
2. The Project Manager will check the PWS each day for notes related to the freon line. They will inspect
the attic if necessary, according to the PWS notes. If the notes state that the freon line is improperly
placed against the roof decking, or the Project Manager discovers this issue during their morning
inspection, the Project Manager and the Crew Leader will coordinate to use one-inch coil nails or
staples on the slope directly above the freon line.
122

Handling Fallout From a Punctured Line
1. Once a line is hit, the crew needs to inform the Project Manager immediately. After notifying the Project
Manager, the crew can continue the roof installation as there is nothing externally that can be done to
mitigate the damage.
2. The Project Manager should contact their manager immediately and wait for further instructions.
3. The manager who received the issue report will contact our HVAC technician and get an estimated
window of arrival at the job site. The manager will then update the Project Manager and the Sales
Representative of the job.
4. The manager will then contact the client and inform them that an improperly installed HVAC line
subcode has been hit by a roofing nail. They will also assure the client that there is no fire hazard or risk
of danger. The manager will also explain that the air conditioning will no longer work once the freon line
loses pressure, which will happen within a few hours. Finally, the manager will inform the client that we
have a trusted HVAC technician who can address the issue at the estimated arrival time.
5. After providing the client with a solution timeline, the manager will explain that this issue is outlined in
the contract and then email or text the client a screenshot of that section of the contract.
a. If the client accepts the news without issue, then the client will cover the repair cost, and no
further action will be taken.
b. If the client pushes back, the manager will tell them that you would like to see what the price is
before further discussion. In that case, the manager will obtain the price from the HVAC
technician and then contact the client.
c. The manager will need to reiterate that this is completely unavoidable, that this is why we have
a disclaimer in the contract and then offer to split the cost. If the client still does not budge or
threatens a negative review, the manager will tell the client that they do not have the authority to
cover the full cost and the situation will be escalated to the Production Director. The Production
Director will handle the situation from here. Costs of up to $1,500 can be approved by the
Production Director; anything over must be a joint decision with the Finance Manager.
Ultimately, Accent’s goal is to protect the profit, client experience, and the company’s reputation. All factors
must be considered when deciding whether or not to cover more than $1,500. Any cost that Accent is going to

through text or email, regarding the color selection.

the client.

dried in and put the crew on temporary standby.

2. The Project Manager will next contact their director manager for guidance.

We’ve shared a lot of concepts and sayings throughout this handbook, but we saved one of the best for last:
Slotivation.
Slotivation is the combination of discipline and motivation.
Motivation matters—but it isn’t enough on its own. If we relied solely on motivation, our lives and careers would
swing between incredible highs and frustrating lows, because motivation comes and goes like the weather.
You can ride a wave of motivation and accomplish a great deal, and you can take steps to spark it more
consistently—but lasting success requires pairing it with discipline.
Here’s how we live out Slotivation:
1. Do what fuels your fire. Whether it’s prayer, rest, family time, church, or something else—make sure you
are spiritually and mentally recharged.
2. Stay solution-focused and encourage others. Lifting someone else up can often be the key to lifting
yourself, even on the hardest days.
3. When motivation fades, fall back on discipline. Rely on the systems in place, the basics of our process,
and your personal routines to keep moving forward until motivation returns.
That’s Slotivation.
